Subject: The Founding of Nottinghack 1st Open Meet-up
Description:
Organisers and new members will meet to socialise and discuss the future of Nottinghack - A Hacker Space for Nottingham all welcome!

Register now on Meetup.com or email the organisers or turn up on the night.

watch this space for more information.

Where?

The Old Salutation Inn Maid Marrion Way/Hounds Gate Nottingham City Centre.

You will know us by Looking out for the Nottinghack Logo! An archer who voids warranties!

Subject: 2nd Meetup  - Welcome new members & Optional Project Show-&-Tell
Description:
It's been a busy week for Nottinghack 7 new members! Organisers attended the first LAB workshop on the 16th. Dominic and JP to Maker Faire UK on the 13th... And much to plan for the future!

The meetup is open to all both prospective and registered hackers. We'll be doing a Show-&-Tell, Doc Little will show his energy monitoring kit and I will show a simple project with Arduino to control a digital camera!

You'll know us by the white hardhat with the Nottinghack and Hackspace foundation logos on (see last meetup photos).

See you there! There are NO newbies at Nottinghack, just folk who value and share skills! Absolutely everyone who is interested is welcome.

Dominic Morrow

Subject: Hack-A-Toy
Description:
Buy (or bring) a pound shop toy Something that moves forward (mechanical or electronic) and hack it... Bring a box of bits and bobs, some tools, soldering irons etc ideally be prepared to share!

At about 9:30 we'll race them in pairs (we'll work out some simple rules on the night).

Alternativly hack your toy anyway you wish!

The meetup ends at 10:30 then tidy up and down to the bar for geek talk etc. Post comments and suggestions once you've RSVP'd

You may bring as much additional technology (micro controller, motors, power etc) as you please!

This time there will be a £2 entry cost the idea being we donate to the Nottinghack fund (we'll need a treasurer) to use each other tools and bits n bobs.

Put your name on your tools if your worried about loosing them.

Subject: Drawdio Hack & Soldering 101
Description:
A workshop and hack meet for all levels of experience. The Drawdio kit is very hackable and a good kit for getting started with soldering.

For the Beginner -

We provide the full kit to make and keep and tools (soldering iron, solder and everything else you need to get started) as well as "step-by-step" instructions projected as Matt Little takes you through making the kit. Experienced hackers will be there to help you too. Soldering is great fun and you'll pick-up the basics in no time at all.

For the Progressor -

Get the kit or buy one of your own. Bring your own tools if you like or share with others. We'll provide printed instruction if you want to rush ahead. Why not hack the kit to make it better. Help beginners by sharing your experience of soldering.

For the Pro (Jedi Level) -

Share your knowledge and help others learn to solder. The PCB will be available so you don't have to get the kit, use your own components, hack the kit and make it awesome!

There are lots of ways to enjoy this hack session and options to suit every level of experience and every pocket too!

Pricing for this workshop -

2 AAA Batteries needed for the kit - Batteries will not be provided
(think of the planet use rechargeables)

£10 - Full Drawdio kit to make and keep access to soldering tools and tuition.

OR

£3 - PCB only, bring your own components and tools

OR

£2 - Bring your own kit, project and tools. Come along for the experience.

There are limited numbers of kits and places on this workshop.

Pay on the night as we don't have any prepayment set-up just yet. To help Nottinghack (as we get started) we could use as many soldering irons, wire cutters/strippers, de-solder tools, 3rd hand or blue-tak, and multi-socket adaptors as possible. If you have a bag of components you don't mind sharing bring them too.

Any questions or concerns please email a member of the leadership team. Full refunds are available.

Subject: Hack-N-Yak - An Open Hack Night & Social
Description:
Hack-N-Yak Open Hack Social

No fee and no limit to places, pop down for a chat or just to find out more about Nottinghack.

Stuff that will be going on at this session:


  • Bring your own projects to hack or share with others (I'll be bringing my kite photography rig)
  • Drawdio kits will be available (cost 10 pounds) if you'd like to make one
  • Diary Update - We'll be planning future events
  • BIG Weekender - We'll chat about the Rube Goldberg event in early June
  • Have a chat and a beer!


We'll use the Navigation Conference Room till about 22:00 then pop down to the bar. This is intended to be a very open unplanned social, rather than a themed and planned hack session, though as usual you can bring any projects and tools you like!

Broadmarsh Shopping Centre car park on Collin Street is the best parking (I'm told).

Subject: Rube Goldberg Evening Hack-N-Drive #1
Description:
A planning evening for the BIG Rube Goldberg Weekender:

- Rube Goldberg videos
- Blue Paper Planning
- Inventory check
- Drop off gear for the BIG Rube Goldberg Weekender

Also a drop in social with Geek Chat for Hackers new & old. Bring your own projects down too if you like. It's an open forum so anything goes.

This is the first Hack-N-Drive session at a new out-of-town venue. It's very close to bus stops on all NCT Green Routes (alight at The Globe on London Road or just before Trent Bridge) and is only 5 mins from the Station.

Venue - The Trent Navigation, Meadow Lane. This is a change in venue from usual even through the name is so similar.

The Trent Navigation has good food and real ale as well as parking.




Members Comments:
This venue has parking so if you have a car and items for the BIG Weekender please bring them. We have lots of storage space at this venue. Please DO bring wood off cuts, MDF sheet or hard/chip board. Items of interest. Tripods, frames or anything to add height. We basically need a huge variety of stuff. Please DON'T bring anything that could be considered as undesirable waste.

Subject: The BIG Rube Goldberg Weekender - Open Event (SAT & SUN)
Description:
The BIG Rube Goldberg Weekender

A major event over 2 days Sat 5th June 2010 and Sun 6th June 2010 with various events (to be posted soon) leading up to it, including an evening of Rube Goldberg which is mostly planning and beer!

Nottinghack have secured a venue, the Trent Navigation Inn (not to be confused with our regular venue The Navigation) for building for fun a Rube Goldberg Machine (see the discussion post). The event will be publicised and open to new and non-members. The idea to have it over a weekend allows for people to "drop-in".

Many more details can be found on Dominic's blog the "Missing Eyebrow"

Please do post ideas up on the discussion board or email a member of the leadership team for more information, questions or requests.

We'd ideally like some film makers to help.

Subject: 1st SUGRU NottingHACKquarium - Hack Stuff Better!
Description:
For more information about SUGRU
www.sugru.com

Nottinghack has acquired some SUGRU which promises to be a very versatile and popular product for hacking. A super-putty which can be moulded, stuck to almost anything, with a firm rubbery feel and dries at room temperature...

Checkout the ideas on Sugru.com and bring something to hack better they'll be a few standard tools around but do bring some along.

As well as messing about with SUGRU we'll have our usual open meet-up where any project can be hacked. Bring your diary as well be deciding the next few months of events dates as well. We'll be chatting through the lessons learned from the Rube Goldberg weekend as well as some news about plans for the next few months.

We've got 20 packs of Sugru only so the first 20 to RSVP get first refusal. The meet up is open to everyone though.

Hope to see you there.

Subject: Hack-in-the-Box - Circuit Bending & You'll-Fix-It
Description:
As usual Nottinghack will provide 2 events in 1!

Circuit Bending

For those who like to make weird noises! Get yourself an old noise making electronic device (car-boot-sale, freeshop, £1Shop, raid the toy box) can be a noisy toy or musical instrument. Open it up & mess about with it's innards until you've found how to make it make strange noises! Some tools will be provided but You'll need to bring your own electronics to hack!

You'll-Fix-It
Broken your iPod, iPhone, digicam, laptop or other gadget? Feel you should have the skills & confidence to open it up & fix it yourself, of course you do your a hacker... but it's always nice to get a few pointers. David will help you learn about opening up gadgets, where to look for help, things to watch out for 7 some tips & tricks. Some tools provided, bring your broken gadget too. Please note YOU fix it, this is to help you learn to fix your own stuff!

As usual you can come along & do none of these things or both as you please. We're at the Navigation on Wilford St Nottingham. Free parking is available on Castle Boulevard after 18:00. The Navigation doesn't do food in the evenings but it usually has a good beer or two.


Members Comments:
John The free parking is somewhere near the Multi York Shop. On the right hand side as you head towards QMC or on the left hand side if you are heading towards the pub. It's about 5 min walk. Michael and I both parked there for the SUGRU night. Dominic

Subject: Hack-the-Space a first look at the Nottingham Hackspace
Description:
The big news is that we have used some of the funds we've made over the last 6 months to secure the use of space at The Art Org on Station Street, Nottingham. This will be Nottingham Hackspace the home of Nottinghack.

We don't have anything at all set up yet. We'll be looking for folk to become paid members of the space (with privileges etc) we'll still do the meetup and workshops for free.

This meetup is an opportunity to see (the empty) space, find out more about the project and even become a founding member.

The Art Org is an ideal space in a great central location. The rent and arrangement we have is very reasonable and can grow with us. As part of the deal with the Landlords we'll be doing a few hours volunteer work at the Art Org, particularly electrical.

To find the space look for the green door next to the mini-Tesco on Station Street Nottingham.

Subject: Open Hack Nights at the Hackspace
Description:
Hack at The Hackspace

Every Wednesday the Hackspace will be open for drop-in hacking. You can choose to do your own thing, just hang out or join in if we've a planned activity or workshop. Bring your own tools and projects or use some of the growing selection of Hackspace shared tools.

Literally almost anything is suitable for doing in the Hackspace including:
Robotics, electronics, programming, knitting, crafts, woodwork, bike repair. You can bring any project to the Hackspace you like as long as it's (fairly) safe and doesn't disturb others... but if you are not sure contact one of the Organisers for guidance.

We now offer membership for £20 a month or you can just pay £3 on the night. More information about membership or visiting costs will be posted later this month.

To get into the Hackspace come through the green door in the photo and buzz the intercom for 2nd floor workshop

Subject: ARDUINO-SUNDAE - 1 Day Workshop - Introduction to Arduino
Description:
This event is open to members and non-members alike as an introduction to hacking & Arduino

An introduction to Arduino for beginners.

Step by step introduction to working with the Arduino prototyping board and an introduction to microprocessors in general. In addition to on-screen step-by-step instruction, experienced hackers will be there to help you. Includes an Arduino Kit or bring your own for a discount.



A day filled with Arduino using the www.oomlout.co.uk Budget Arduino Kit (included in the cost of the workshop or buy and bring your own for a discount).

Schedule for the day:

11:00 - Settle in get your kit open it up and have a play around meet others etc
11:30 - "Hello World" Arduino 101 basic Arduino introduction including setting up external LEDs, Motors and sensors etc
12:30 - Show n' Tell - Arduino-Projects-Show-Case a number of projects including - Drawbot, Arduino Tank, 3D Printer RepRap, Addressable lights and many more (bring one too if you like) will be available for inspiration, discussion and tuition.
13:30 Lunch (bring your own or pop to a local place we are very central)
1400 - Use the pool of parts to try your own project. Helpful and experienced hackers want to help you learn more and will circulate to answer your questions. At Nottinghack there are no stupid questions.
16:00 - Close (but your welcome to stay until 18:00 then we'll probably go for a coffee or beer).

Have a think about what you'd like to learn. We have a few suggested projects to help people who aren't sure and there will be lots or electronic bits n' bobs to help you get stuck in.

Make sure you bring your laptop and download the Arduino Open Source environment and install it before the workshop

http://www.arduino.cc...

The cost of the workshop is only £40 including the Oomlout Budget Pack for Arduino and a day of tuition and hands on help. If you already have an Arduino and the required equipment the cost is £20 only.

Subject: Drawdio Hack II - Learn to Solder Open Hack Night
Description:
A workshop and hack meet for all levels of experience. The Drawdio kit is very hackable and a good kit for getting started with soldering.

For the Beginner -

We provide the full kit to make and keep and tools (soldering iron, solder and everything else you need to get started) as well as "step-by-step" instructions projected as Matt Little takes you through making the kit. Experienced hackers will be there to help you too. Soldering is great fun and you'll pick-up the basics in no time at all.

For the Progressor -

Get the kit or buy one of your own. Bring your own tools if you like or share with others. We'll provide printed instruction if you want to rush ahead. Why not hack the kit to make it better. Help beginners by sharing your experience of soldering.

For the Pro (Jedi Level) -

Share your knowledge and help others learn to solder. The PCB will be available so you don't have to get the kit, use your own components, hack the kit and make it awesome!

There are lots of ways to enjoy this hack session and options to suit every level of experience and every pocket too!

Subject: 2nd Sugru Hackquarium Open Hack Night
Description:
For more information about SUGRU
www.sugru.com

Nottinghack has acquired some SUGRU which promises to be a very versatile and popular product for hacking. A super-putty which can be moulded, stuck to almost anything, with a firm rubbery feel and dries at room temperature...

Checkout the ideas on Sugru.com and bring something to hack better they'll be a few standard tools around but do bring some along.

As well as messing about with SUGRU we'll have our usual open meet-up where any project can be hacked. Bring your diary as well be deciding the next few months of events dates as well. We'll be chatting through the lessons learned from the Rube Goldberg weekend as well as some news about plans for the next few months.

We've got 20 packs of Sugru only so the first 20 to RSVP get first refusal. The meet up is open to everyone though.

Hope to see you there.

Subject: General Normal Open Hacking & Tidy Up the Store Room
Description:
After having a frankly mad October at the Hackspace with many big ticket events we're going to kick back and tidy the store room.

It's an Open hack night. That means bring your own project or simply pop down to do some quiet reading, programming, or just have a good geeky natter and a cuppa.

We'll be reviewing the Laser Maze from last week. Might also be scheduling more volunteer electronics for the Art Org. There are plans afoot to move to the 1st floor and there is plenty of very cool things to be done to make that space more hackspace like.

Any questions or comments please contact one of the leadership team.

Not been before? Just pop down, the first visit is always free & no-one need pay a penny if they don't like it.

Subject: Circuit Bending 101
Description:
Learn the basics of circuit bending - modifying the circuits in battery-operated toys to produce new sounds.

Over three projects we will:

  • Use potentiometers and light dependent resistors to change speed and pitch
  • Add in blinky lights
  • Use short circuits to distort sounds
  • Add body contacts to distort sounds
  • Loop sounds
  • Add audio output sockets so you can make those distorted bleepy noises LOUDER


<iframe src="http://player.vimeo.c... width="400" height="300" style="margin : 5px ; max-width : 700px ; max-height : 700px"></iframe>

Circuit Bending 101 from nikkipugh on Vimeo.


Places are limited to 12 attendees only, so snap up a place if you want to come and don't forget to let us know if you then can't attend, so we can offer your place to someone else.

The workshops costs £30, payable on the door. This price includes instruction, all the materials you need (feel free to bring your own soldering equipment and wire cutters etc if you don't want to share) and some food (make sure you let us know of any dietary requirements).

The workshop will finish at about 6pm.

Under 16s must be accompanied by a responsible adult. Be aware that we'll be using soldering irons and power tools so it's not very suitable for little 'uns.

The workshop will be led by Nikki Pugh: freelance artist and part of the core team at Birmingham hackspace fizzPOP. Turns out she's also rather fond of strange bleepy noises...

www.npugh.co.uk

Subject: Lock-picking & open hack night
Description:
Learn the basics of opening locks, with lock-picks and other bypass methods :)

Starting from 6pm until 8pm I'll be taking people through the basics of how a pin tumbler lock works (the most common household lock) and discussing how various picking techniques open locks.

I've got a selection of different lock types to demonstrate and will be providing tuition an opportunities for people to practice the techniques demonstrated.

I can only bring a limited selection of tools at present, but if there is enough interest, we may look into getting a practice set for the hack-space for future sessions.

We will also be discussing home security in general, with hints and tips on what you can do to better protect your home & possessions.

Also, the Hackspace will be open for drop-in hacking. You can choose to do your own thing, just hang out or join in the lockpicking workshop. Bring your own tools and projects or use some of the growing selection of Hackspace shared tools.

Literally almost anything is suitable for doing in the Hackspace including:
Robotics, electronics, programming, knitting, crafts, woodwork, bike repair. You can bring any project to the Hackspace you like as long as it's (fairly) safe and doesn't disturb others... but if you are not sure contact one of the Organisers for guidance.

We now offer membership for £20 a month or you can just pay £3 on the night. More information about membership or visiting costs will be posted later this month.

Subject: Learn To Solve The Rubik's Cube
Description:
Learn To Solve The Rubik's Cube!

Ever wanted to solve the world's most popular puzzle? This meetup will be a hands-on tutorial with a small amount of theory.

I'll be teaching an intuitive beginners' method that is easy to perform, and easy to remember. Furthermore this is a method designed to be built upon for speedcubing and for solving other twisty puzzles.

Cubes and notes will be provided for you to take home and perfect your newly achieved skills!

I've obtained a batch of very reputable speedcubes from a supplier in HongKong (Black Ghost Hand II, and White YJ II cubes). The cost of the meetup covers the price of a cube plus a small amount towards the Hackspace.

Subject: An introduction to lockpicking
Description:
After the success of the last event & interest from members & non-members who couldn't make it, I've decided to run 2 more sessions to introduce people to the techniques of picking locks & lock-sport as a hobby.

The two sessions will run on Monday 17th January from 6-9pm and Saturday the 22nd of January from 12-3pm, to allow people who can't make events on a "school night" or on a weekend to attend. Both sessions will be open to all, including those who have attended previous sessions, however spaces are limited to 15 people for each event, to ensure there are enough tools & locks for everyone.

I'll be taking people through the basics of how a pin tumbler lock works (the most common household lock) and discussing how various picking techniques open locks with lock picks and other bypass methods :)

I've got a selection of different lock types to demonstrate and will be providing tuition an opportunities for people to practice the techniques demonstrated.

I can only bring a limited selection of tools at present, but if there is enough interest, we may look into getting a practice set for the hack-space for future sessions.

We will also be discussing home security in general, with hints and tips on what you can do to better protect your home & possessions.

A £4 contribution to the hackspace has been suggested, to cover the cost of running these events & I'm hoping to have a selection of locks, books & tools to be left out for members to use, either during drop in hackspace sessions, or in their own time.

Subject: How To Workshop: Make a Circuit Board
Description:
Get the basics of PCB (Printed Circuit Board) manufacture from Nottinghack's Matt Little (from our Soldering & Drawdio Workshops).

There are many processes and techniques for making a printed circuit board (PCB).
In this session Matt will guide you through his process for making PCBs, this involves:


  • Design of PCB
  • UV photoresist
  • Etch
  • Drill


Matt uses a mixture of home-made and bought tools. He will highlight some of the problems and share some of the tips and tricks he's uses.

You will get to create and keep a circuit board for a simple LED flashing circuit (components included).

The circuit board layout is made using the open source software called KiCad (for both Linux and Windows). If you have a (small) circuit you would like created then bring along your completed PCB design and we can make that with you!

This session will cost £8. In this session we will develop and make the circuit board and (if time) you can solder up the circuit to create a simple LED flasher. All tools supplied.

Please do tell us about your own PCB manufacture methods

Don't want to make a circuit board? It's Open Hack Night so please do come and join us that's FREE as always! Only pay if you take part in the workshop!


* Please note the image is NOT the circuit you'll make on this workshop (just a picture)

Subject: Fab Camp Liverpool
Description:
http://fabcampliverpo...
The advent of digital fabrication (the production of physical objects from digital information) represents a revolution in the way we design, produce and consume the objects around us.
New techniques, such as 3D printing, allow us to conceive and produce objects that couldnât have been built in any other way 5 years ago.
The cost for the necessary equipment and software has dropped to a level that makes them accessible from the desktop PC.
The increasing availability of learning materials has lowered the barrier to acquiring the necessary skills.
All of this provides the opportunity for us to become producers of the objects around us rather than consumers.
There are approximately 300,000 people involved in professional product design in the UK, whereas there are over 3,000,000 people now designing and making inventions to meet their own needs in the UK alone.
The question is, do you want to join them?

Subject: Nottingham Light Night
Description:
Nottingham Light Night

Nottingham Hackspace propose to take a number of light based projects out onto the streets as an unofficial part of Light Night on 18th Feb 2011.

To find out more about the official events on Light Night please go here

Projects we have in mind are:



  • Bikes with POV on the wheels
  • Projects using EL Wire like Tron perhaps
  • Projection onto Hackspace windows
  • Laser and Light Sensitive Paints perhaps on Sandwich Boards


Please post any additional ideas below. We'll meet at the hackspace from 6:00pm keep an eye on the weather and dress warm. There should be plenty to see and do as well as our own projects. We'll go back to the (pub) Hackspace about 09:30pm to warm up.

Subject: Hackers-On-A-BUS - Maker Faire UK 2011 in Newcastle DAY 1
Description:
Maker Faire UK Newcastle 2011

The world-famous Maker Faire returns to the UK to headline Newcastle ScienceFest. Expect a weekend of cool robots, garden-shed inventions, knitted wonders, the occasional fireball and oodles of opportunities to make your own creations. Perfect for creative people of all ages!

Maker Faire 2011 is likely to be the biggest yet. Many of the other Hackspaces that have formed in 2010 will be there too.



We plan to hire a mini-bus: Rough details from a recent Google Groups email here:

Likely costs for Maker Faire Newcastle:

I'd anticipate that costs for this trip are going to be about £75/£125 as
follows:

2x £5 - MAKER FAIRE ENTRY - Based on last years price
£12 - SEAT ON BUS - 17 seat Mini Bus Hire - £189 / 17
http://www.eastmidshi...
£4/£6 - FUEL SHARE - Share of Based on 330 miles at 30 miles per
gallon 11 gallons approx. 50L at avg. £1.20 per Litre

£50 - HOTEL - Premier Inn Newcastle South -
http://www.premierinn...
Obviously we can try and tweak this on the hotel cost I just chose the
cheapest Premier Inn and haven't looked at other hotels or cheaper B&B
options or anything like that. We might even be able to wangle some
sort of group booking if we do something about it now. Ideally our
hotel needs to have parking, be in Newcastle proper (this one is in
Gateshead) be about £30 - £40, ideally walking distance to the venue
which is about 2 mins from the station.

We'd probably drop you back to your door if you live in Nottingham or
there about.

The quoted price is for transport. If we get a higher number of interested people we'll try and get a bigger bus. You'll be responsible for your own accommodation, food & ticket entry costs for the faire itself.

We'll be asking for a deposit at least 1 month prior to the Faire. You'll need to have paid your deposit by the 12th February 2011 or we'll make your place available to someone else.

Subject: Uncaged Monkeys
Description:
The first ever national science tour celebrating the universe and many of the wonders that lie within it. The finest names in science broadcasting gather together to talk of dark matter, black holes, Bonobo apes, the big bang and anything else they can cram into two hours.

Robin Ince, co-presenter of BBC Radio 4's Infinite Monkey Cage and creator of the sell out smash Nine Lessons and Carols for Godless People will be introducing great minds of science including...

Professor Brian Cox, the other presenter of Infinite Monkey Cage, is also writer and presenter of Wonders of The Solar System and soon to be aired Wonders of the Universe.

Dr Ben Goldacre, author of Bad Science and slayer of bamboozlers.

Simon Singh, author of the best-selling and award winning Fermat's Last Theorem, as well as Big Bang and Trick Or Treatment.

A night like no other, mixing live presentations and fabulous projections of the phenomenal.

Prepare to be amazed.

http://www.royalcentr...

http://www.robinince....

http://www.badscience...

Subject: Chaos Communication Camp 2011
Description:
The Chaos Communication Camp is an international meeting of hackers that takes place every four years, organized by the Chaos Computer Club (CCC). Previous sessions have taken place in 1999 and 2003 at the Paulshof next to Altlandsberg near Berlin.
The camp is an event for providing information about technical and societal issues, such as privacy, freedom of information and data security. Hosted speeches are held in big tents and conducted in English as well as German. Each participant may pitch a tent and connect to a fast internet connection and power.
The 2007 event took place at Finowfurt (near Berlin) from the 8th to the 12th of August.
The next camp will take place from the 10th to the 14th of August 2011 in Finowfurt.

Subject: Chaos Communication Camp 2011
Description:
The Chaos Communication Camp is an international meeting of hackers that takes place every four years, organized by the Chaos Computer Club (CCC). Previous sessions have taken place in 1999 and 2003 at the Paulshof next to Altlandsberg near Berlin.
The camp is an event for providing information about technical and societal issues, such as privacy, freedom of information and data security. Hosted speeches are held in big tents and conducted in English as well as German. Each participant may pitch a tent and connect to a fast internet connection and power.
The 2007 event took place at Finowfurt (near Berlin) from the 8th to the 12th of August.
The next camp will take place from the 10th to the 14th of August 2011 in Finowfurt.
